Hi,

Assume you have an application with bronze, silver, and gold "tiers" for which you charge $1, $2, and $3 respectively. Let's say you can click on one button with bronze, two buttons with silver, and three buttons with gold.

Do you hard-code these business rules, or do you use a rules-engine? What is your go-to way to implement things like trials, discounts, etc. in the product?

What is your go-to way to fragment all the features into a feature grid/matrix and grant/deny/limit/meter access to any given feature on the fly? Do you have successful examples using rules engines for that?

Thank you,
stories.title: Ask HN: How do you implement business rules for product assortments and tiers?

stories.text:
Hey, We are building a grocery delivery platform (Glist), where you could get up to 100% discount on groceries, vegetables, meat & fish.

But when I talk this, that we can provide up to 100% discounts (I mean free), no one is ready to believe it.

We do that through invitations (referral marketing). When you invite your friends and when they make a purchase through us, you get a percentage of the sale, as wallet balance. It's not 1 time, but whenever they purchase you get a referral percentage for the sale. We provide 1% of the total sales as referral commission, which is not huge at all. But when the volume increases, that becomes big for the customer.

For example: let's say you buy $400 worth of groceries every month. So when you refer, one of your friends, who also buy $400 worth of products through us, you get a $4 (1%) instant discount on your next purchase.

If you were able to refer, 100 such customers who buy $400 worth of groceries every month, you will be able to get $400 discounts every month, that's a 100% discount for your monthly groceries.

100 referrals might seem hard to reach. But we help our customers through educational content/videos to reach that level using simple social media and online marketing techniques, by providing all their customized marketing materials.

------------------ I would like to know what's your take on this idea. It's a simple idea.
stories.title: Who like to get their monthly groceries to be free?
